Russian is the native language of the majoraty of Northwestern Russia inhabitants. Important minority languages are: Finnish, Karelian and Veps languages in Karelia republic and Komi language in Komi republic. Almost all Finnish, Karelain, Komi and Veps speakers are bilingual and are fluent in Russian, aside from their native languages.

Basic English is widely understood in big cities, while in smaller cities and the countryside it can be very difficult to find an English speaker.
can also be useful. Older generations (over 30 years old) are less familiar with foreign languages than younger people.

The principal mode of transport in Northwestern Russia (and

generally) is rail. Saint Petersburg is the undisputed rail hub of the region, and virtually all major cities in the region have rail service direct to the "Northern Capital." Southern cities also have direct service to

. Given the vast distances throughout this sparsely populated section of the world, overnight trains are the most frequent mode of transport.

For intra-oblast travel, the most efficient and simple mode of transport are the electric train lines (
: электрички
. These small suburban radiate out from the main cities not just to suburbs, but to far-off smaller cities as well as small villages.
If the elektrichki don't take you all the way to your destination, you are in for an adventure. Buses and their smaller cousins (
: маршрутки

) connect the rest of the small towns and villages to the broader transit system. It is rare, however, to see a bus that has a clearly marked route. Often the only way to know which bus to take, and for that matter when to get off, is to
. If you don't have enough command of Russian to do so, consider finding a tour operator to arrange transport to your destination instead.
